prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Choice of bands:
Since the goal is to reveal the first observational constraints on quite uncertain physical conditions and chemistry, we must perform as unbiased a survey as possible while simultaneously making the most useful measurements of the molecules we know are present based on Cycle 0 (CO and SiO).
To calculate excitation temperatures and abundances, we require at least two lines of each molecular species, and we need two bands (band 6 & 7) to cover two CO lines. These two bands are best choice as the gas temperature of 10-130 K is best optimized at this frequency ranges and the lines are still reasonably isolated. CO and SiO are covered with these two settings, but also SiS, SO and CS will be detected.
Currently, the spectral scan mode in the OT does not take into account any shared calibration, e.g. separate Tsys measurements are made for every tuning, every time the phase calibrator is observed. If the observatory perfects shared calibration and resolves all phase offset issues, the calibration overhead for this proposal can be significantly reduced, perhaps as much as 50%.
Sensitivity:
Our cycle-0 proposal detected CO J=2-1 line to have 20 mJy peak flux density. Our non-LTE modelling of CO J=1-0 and 2-1, together with Herschel J=7-6 ad 8-7 CO lines (Kamenetzky et al. 2013) shows that CO J=2-1 line is optically thick, and we predict CO J=3-2 to be 50-60 mJy.
We modelled the expected line intensities for other species using an LTE (Matsuura et al. 2013) radiative transfer code, taking into account the relative molecular abundances from Sarangi and Cherchneff (2013), isotope ratios from Heger & Woosley (and no isotopic fractionation) and the CO J=2-1 optical depth from Kamenetzky et al. (2013). We assumed an excitation temperature of 50 K. Expected bright lines are SiS (>10 mJy) , on top of SiO and CO. SO is also bright (~2mJy).
Minimum 13CO line intensities are predicted to be 0.3-0.8 mJy (probably up to 7 mJy) and 0.6-2 mJy (probably up to 15 mJy) for J=2-1 and 3-2; this is higher than the intensities simply scaled by the 12C/13C abundance ratio because the main line is optically thick.
Similarly, SiS and SO isotopologues, with 1-10 percent of the main isotopologue abundance, should have flux densities of one to a few mJy.
The required sensitivities are set to 0.15 mJy from 210-300 GHz and 0.2 mJy from 300-350 GHz at 1000 km s-1 resolution in post-observing process.
The spectral resolutions are 40 km s-1 and 30 km s-1 for band 6 and band 7, respectively. These resolution are sufficient to resolve the velocity profiles of bright lines (CO, SiO and SiS) Continuum levels are about 4 mJy for band 7, arising from dust thermal emission. Band 6 continuum is below 2mJy (expected to be about 1.2 mJy). These also be detected.
Imaging:
The angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec was chosen to match the size of the ejecta, and resolve it from the shocked circumstellar ring (2” in size).
Correlator setup: The wide line is expected to be 2000 km s-1 (FWHM). We chose the largest bandwidth of 2150 km s-1, which makes the line survey the most efficient. The current spectral resolution is set to 35.8 km s-1, that is sufficient to determine the velocity profiles of bright lines. We will smooth the spectra 1000 km s -1 in post-observing process for the faint lines.
Calibration: Default calibration is sufficient.
Bandpass accuracy: standard
Scheduling/time constraints: no scheduling constraints (but see trading of observing time with cycle-1 programme)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Supernovae (SNe) are the main source of chemical enrichment in galaxies. SN 1987A was the nearest SN explosion detected in 400 years. Since its discovery, SN 1987A has given us remarkable insights into the physics and chemistry of SNe.
Our ALMA Cycle-0 detected molecular line emission in the SN ejecta, thus opened up an exciting new avenue of observational research, molecular astronomy in SNe.
In this cycle-2 programme we propose an unbiased line survey of SN 1987A from 210 to 350 GHz. We aim to detect new species of molecules that have been predicted to form in SN ejecta, and to measure the emission from the isotopologues of these molecules, as well as their velocity profiles, densities and temperatures.
Measurements of molecular isotopologue ratios will allow us to measure isotope ratios of C, O, S, Si. This will provide direct constraints on stellar yields from SN nuclosynthesis. These measurements of abundances for species other than CO and SiO will constrain not only chemical models. We will also measure the line profiles from different molecular species, tracing turbulent structure that resulted from the hydrodynamical instabilities caused by the SN explosion.
